During our research, we have asked the public about their support for various farming practices. Opinions varied significantly, but chicken cages emerged as the practice with the highest support for a ban. These cages were viewed as having the least necessity and one of the highest levels of harm. Conversely, farming animals for food had the highest perceived necessity, the lowest harm rating, and the least support for a ban.

This highlighted an intriguing inverse relationship between perceived harm, necessity, and support for a ban. Specifically, the greater the perceived harm and the lower the perceived necessity, the stronger the support for a ban.

By targeting policies that already have high levels of public support, it should be much easier to mobilise around the issue and have the policy passed at a national level. Additionally, by emphasizing the harm and redundancy of cruel practices in our messaging, we can influence public support for bans.

The goal of a social movement is simple: to change public opinion. But what exactly does the process of changing public opinion look like? The answer lies in momentumâ€”a collective effort of many people taking escalating actions over time.ğŸ§ It's kind of like a snowball rolling down a hill, growing larger along the way and attracting more supporters to the cause. ğŸš€

In a recent discussion with the Sentience Institute Podcast, our Direction Lead, Laila Kassam, PhD, elaborated on the role of non-violent direct action within the 'cycle of momentum', an organising model advocated by Mark and Paul Enger in 'This is an Uprising' to build mass protest movements:

She explained, "Movements grow cyclically, and the cycle of momentum consists of three parts: ğ™šğ™¨ğ™˜ğ™–ğ™¡ğ™–ğ™©ğ™ğ™¤ğ™£, ğ™–ğ™—ğ™¨ğ™¤ğ™§ğ™¥ğ™©ğ™ğ™¤ğ™£, ğ™–ğ™£ğ™™ ğ™ğ™£ğ™˜ğ™§ğ™šğ™–ğ™¨ğ™šğ™™ ğ™–ğ™˜ğ™©ğ™ğ™«ğ™š, ğ™¥ğ™¤ğ™¥ğ™ªğ™¡ğ™–ğ™§ ğ™¨ğ™ªğ™¥ğ™¥ğ™¤ğ™§ğ™©. We're delighted to present the next free webinar in our ongoing series on Narrative Change for Animal Freedom. 

This Introduction to Narrative Change and Worldviews will be led by our Narrative Lead, Beth Thomas.

ğŸ—“ Wednesday 10 May, 4:30 - 5:30 pm BST

ğŸ“Online - register at https://bit.ly/3M25uZj (or search eventbrite.com for 'narrative change', the event will come up). 

More info: 

Narratives and worldviews make up the foundational ways we make sense of the world, find meaning and distinguish right from wrong.

In this public webinar, Beth will explore how we can change these fundamental beliefs to win Animal Freedom. We'll discover dominant narratives and worldviews in the modern world and the potential power of reawakening old ones.
